app.text_info: This app is created by locals and experts. As you can see, it's also free of charge. Please let us know if you want to contribute with your experience, enrich the content, correct inaccuracies, or submit pictures.
app.text_acknowledge: This quick app is an open-source project powered by open data and enriched by the community. Most of the information was extracted from Wikidata, OpenStreetMaps, and other public sources. You can find inaccuracies, so we apologize in advance.
app.text_feedback: Please let us know if you want to contribute with your experience, enrich the content, correct inaccuracies, or submit pictures. This app is created by locals and experts.

pois.name: Chocolate Museum
pois.description: This museum is dedicated to the art of chocolate-making.
pois.more: Visitors can take workshops to learn about the process from cacao bean to chocolate bar and even make their own chocolates.

pois.name: Church of San Pedro
pois.description: This small church, located in the San Pedro neighborhood, is often overlooked by tourists. It features beautiful colonial architecture and offers a peaceful respite from the crowds.

pois.name: Pre-Columbian Art Museum
pois.description: While not as well-known as some other museums in Cuzco, it houses an impressive collection of pre-Columbian art, including pottery, textiles, and sculptures.

pois.name: Stone of the twelth angles
pois.description: The not so famous but incredibly stone of 12!!! angles. Located at the citadel of Machu Picchu
pois.more: Can you believe that Incas made that with its own bare hands

pois.name: Planetarium
pois.description: Located a bit outside the city, this planetarium offers an interesting perspective on Inca astronomy and their understanding of the cosmos

pois.name: Machu Picchu
pois.description: While not in Cuzco itself, it's worth mentioning that Cuzco is often the starting point for the journey to Machu Picchu, one of the most iconic archaeological sites in the world.

pois.name: Vinicunca
pois.description: Vinicunca, also called Monta√±a de Siete Colores (Mountain of Seven Colors), is located in the Andes in the Cusco region of Peru, and until 2013 when the ice that had always covered the mountain melted away, the colors beneath were completely unknown.
pois.more: The colors look more natural in person, but they're not dull either
